title: Magdeburg Confession
text:
The Magdeburg Confession (officially, the "Confession, Instruction, and Admonition of the pastors and preachers of the Christian congregations of Magdeburg") was a <a href="Lutheran">Lutheran</a> <a href="Creed">statement of faith</a>. It was written by nine pastors of the city of <a href="Magdeburg">Magdeburg</a> in 1550 in response to the <a href="Augsburg%20Interim">Augsburg Interim</a> and the imposition of <a href="Roman%20Catholicism">Roman Catholicism</a>. The Confession explains why the leaders of the city refused to obey the <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">imperial</a> law, and were prepared to resist its implementation with force if necessary. The Magdeburg Confession calls for <a href="Resistance%20theory%20in%20the%20Early%20Modern%20period">resistance</a> to political tyranny, and argues that the "<a href="Lesser%20magistrate">subordinate powers</a>" in a state, faced with the situation where the "supreme power" is working to destroy true religion, may go further than non-cooperation with the supreme power and assist the faithful to resist.
<a href="Carter%20Lindberg">Carter Lindberg</a> calls it "the first Protestant religious justification of the right of defense against unjust higher authorities." <a href="John%20Witte%2C%20Jr.">John Witte</a> notes that <a href="Theodore%20Beza">Theodore Beza</a> saw the Magdeburg Confession as an example of how to respond to political abuse of tyranny, and that it was a "major distillation of the most advanced Lutheran resistance theories of the day, which the Calvinist tradition absorbed."
